summary: Richard A. Sprague is mentioned in the context of payroll records from the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). Document 180-10070-10160 specifically mentions his employment with the HSCA, detailing his payroll authorizations, salary adjustments, and a memorandum regarding payroll certifications. While the majority of the documents focus on payroll records of other HSCA staff and administrative processes like the Assassination Records Review Board's (ARRB) final determination notifications regarding the postponement of Social Security numbers for privacy reasons, Sprague's inclusion indicates he was an employee or contractor of the HSCA. The documents do not provide specific details about his role or responsibilities within the HSCA, only that he was compensated for his services.
significance: Richard A. Sprague's significance in the JFK context is primarily related to his employment with the HSCA, the committee tasked with investigating the assassination. While the documents do not specify his role, his presence on the payroll indicates he was involved in the investigation in some capacity. The lack of detail makes it difficult to assess the depth of his involvement or any specific contributions he made to the HSCA's findings.
